Number 10 Please provide the total spending on low -income ECO programs for 2020 
through 2026 (recognizing that 2025 and 2026 are budgeted) in terms of 
actual dollars and as a percent of residential revenue (based on the 3 -year 
average used for the low -income minimum spend ECO requirement) and as 
a percent of the $50 million proposed for the “clean firm technology fund”

Please see the table below. With respect to the row labeled “% of Clean Firm Technology 
Fund,” please note that these percentages reflect a mathematical ratio of the dollars for low -
income spending to the total amount of the proposed Clean Firm Technology Fund. However, 
the Clean Firm Technology Fund consists of investor -supplied amounts that would be 
incremental to spending on low -income ECO programs.

Subject: Stop BlackRock
This message may be from an external email source.
Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT Services Security
Operations Center.You don't often get email from ellen.munshower@gmail.com . Learn why this is important
Hello,
Please do not allow BlackRock to take over MN power. Private equity firms have been
ruining so many great things (Red Lobster, Joann Fabrics), but now they're threateningpeople's lives. A huge spike in energy bills can put people on the street. Please pleaseplease work for the best interest of the people you represent, and stop BlackRock. MNPower isn't great, BlackRock is SO MUCH WORSE.
Help all of us Minnesotans, that includes people you care about personally, I'm sure.
Thank you,
Ellen Munshower

Additional Info: Received Outside Comment Period- John Munter
content:
This message may be from an external email source.
Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT Services Security
Operations Center.From: John Munter
To: Staff, CAO (PUC) ; John Munter
Subject: Docket 24 24198
Date: Friday, August 29, 2025 4:06:37 PM
You don't often get email from mumooatthefarm@yahoo.com. Learn why this is important
I realize I am late to post a comment but please submit this. I have two points on the purchase of
Blackrock of MN Power that are relevant.  It is obvious Blackrock is looking at an AI data center requiringa renewable energy outbuild since Mn Power's revenue from mining is declining.  Despite HF 16mandating a data center pay upfront for new energy facilities there still could be a cost to rate payers forwhat is determined a "system benefit".  This would be 'regressive progress'. The AI data center shouldalso pay for the 'system benefit' for taxpayers as well based on FERC's foundational doctrine of "Thosewho cause costs to be incurred should bear those costs".  That is number 1.  Number two is that the new
data center should provide a percentage of their services for 'open source'--say 10% which might include
software and transparent architecture since they are being given access to water, space for solar, windfarms, and labor force for the public, academia, media as a free public service.

Additional Info: PUC 8-13 ALLETE, GPP, and CIP QUESTION
content:
Staff Information Request ( PUC 8 - PUC 13 ) 
 
 
8. Please describe current ECO programs that provide customer rebates or directly fund and install air sealing and insulation measures for market -rate residential 
customers and, separately, for low -income residential customers. For each 
program, provide the 2024-2026 planned and actual: 
a. Budgets and actual spending    
b. Participation   
c. Energy savings  
d. Bill savings   
 
9. Please describe current ECO programs that provide customer rebates or directly fund and install air source heat pumps for residential customers and, separately, for low -income residential customers. For each program, provide the 2024- 2026 
planned and actual: 
a. Budgets and spending    
b. Participation   
c. Energy savings  
d. Bill savings   
 
 
10. Please provide the total spending on low-income ECO programs for 2020 through 
2026 (recognizing that 2025 and 2026 are budgeted) in terms of actual dollars and as a percent of residential revenue (based on the 3 -year average used for the low -
income minimum spend ECO requirement) and as a percent of the $50 million 
proposed for the “clean firm technology fund ” 
 
 
 
11. Please provide the total annual average  number of call center staff employed by 
Minnesota Power for the last 5 years and the state in which they primarily work.   
  
12. Please provide the total average number  of Minnesota Power employees for each 
year in the last 5 years and the state in which those employees primarily work.  
  
13. Regarding the $50 million investment by 2030 in a “clean firm technology fund” proposed in the Company's settlement stipulation with the Department of Commerce:   
a. What process, or which specific proceedings, will Minnesota Power 
use to seek Commission approval for investments made out of this fund?   
b. By what date does Minnesota Power anticipate spending down the 
funds in this account?   
c. How many clean firm technology projects, and how much capacity 
(MW), does Minnesota Power anticipate will be made possible by this 
fund? Explain how this estimate was developed and provide examples of 
other clean firm project costs and/or research on expected technology costs to support your answer.   
d. How will Minnesota Power leverage or otherwise maximize the 
effectiveness and ratepayer benefits of this fund?

Additional Info: PUC 14-32 ALLETE, GPP, and CIP QUESTION
content:
Staﬀ IR Request (PUC14 - PUC 3 2) 
Headquarters  
In the initial ﬁling  ALLETE  provided Attachment B which was entitled “AGREEMENT AND PLAN 
OF MERGER by and among ALLETE, INC., ALLOY PARENT LLC and ALLOY MERGER SUB LLC” dated 
May 5, 2024 . On page 66 of that agreement Section 6.06(b)(i)(1) it states:  
“Headquarters. The Company will continue to maintain the headquarters of its regulated businesses in Duluth, Minnesota and Superior, Wisconsin.”  
After the separation that is proposed in 1.27 it is presume d Minnesota Power will be designated 
to be the Minnesota regulated entity and Superior Water Light & Power will be designated to be 
a Wisconsin regulated entity.  
14. Will ALLETE  or its subsidiary retain transmission and generation assets not within these 
two entities, but potentially still regulated by FERC or other jurisdictions?   
15. Would entities managing these assets be considered “regulated businesses” under the 
May 5, 2024  agreement ? 
16. If these entities  are “regulated entities” pursuant to the agreement and those entities’ 
headquarters were removed from Duluth, who would have standing to bring an action 
to enforce the agreement, what would be the speciﬁc action, what venue would such 
action be brought in, and what would be any anticipated remedies for a breach of the 
agreement?  
17. Is there a common accepted understanding regarding the term “headquarters” or 
“headquartered” as use d in the Initial Filing, the May 5, 2024 agreement , and the July 11 
Settlement Stipulation? Please provide what ALLETE  and the Partners understand these 
terms to mean . 
18. If ALLETE  or the Partners  were to violate  paragraph 1.67 of the July 11 Settlement 
Stipulation , who would have standing to bring an action to enforce the agreement, what 
would be the speciﬁc action?   
19. what venue would such action be brought in, and what would be any anticipated 
remedies for a breach of the  settlement stipulation regarding Minnesota Power’s 
headquarters ? 
Workforce and Labor Protections Enforcement  
In the July 11 Settlement Stipulation , Petitioners made commitments regarding “ Workforce and 
Labor Protections ” at paragraphs 1.56 to 1.62 including but not limited to prevailing wages, not 
to lay  oﬀ employees, not to remove the existing leadership team, and not to reduce spending 
on the local community.  
20. For each of these paragraphs , identify how these commitments are enforceable.   
21. Who has standing to bring an action to enforce each of these speciﬁc commitments ? 
22.  What would be the speciﬁc action, what venue s would such actions  be brought in?  
23.  What would be any anticipated remedies for a breach of the  speciﬁc settlement 
stipulation ? 
In the  July 11 Settlement Stipulation , Petitioners made a commitment regarding continued 
funding of economic development activities at 1.66. It stated:  
“For as long as Minnesota Power is owned by the Partners, Minnesota Power will 
maintain historical levels of economic development in the State of Minnesota. ”  
24. How  are ALLETE  and the Partners deﬁning  “historic levels” for comparison  to future 
spending ? 
25.  Is there a speciﬁc annual dollar amount or will that be determined on the date of 
closing?  
26. How will it be determined and will it be speciﬁcally noted in a compliance ﬁling to the Commission  after closing ? 
27.  Who has standing to bring an action to enforce this speciﬁc commitment, what would 
be the speciﬁc action, what venues would such actions be brought in, and what would 
be any anticipated remedies for a breach of this speciﬁc settlement stipulation?  
Sale of Land o r Other Real Property  
Minnesota Power in Docket No. E015/PA -20-675 made several commitments regarding the sale 
of excess land connected to its Hydro facilities in St. Louis County. In particular , Minnesota 
Power committed to refund and credit to customers either in a future rate case or through the 
Renewable Resources Rider all the proceeds from the sale regardless of whether they were in rate base or shareholder assets. These commitments involved actions through 2028 to close on the sale of these properties .  
28. Why is paragraph 1.45 in the July 11 Settlement Stipulation needed if ratepayers  were 
going to be credited with these proceeds  under this prior commitment ?  
29. Are the signers to the July 11 Settlement Stipulation  intending that this “bill credit” will 
be something diﬀerent than the obligations already committed to by ALLETE  and 
Minnesota Power in Docket No. E015/PA -20-675? If so, what is the intent and will it be 
to ratepayer beneﬁt?  
In the July 11 Settlement Stipulation , ALLETE  and the Partners  committed to handling the sale of 
land or other Real property in paragraph 1.46  as follows:  
“Within 60 days of closing of any sale of land or other real property that was included in 
rate base, excluding existing proceeds from land sales identiﬁed in Docket No. E015/PA -
20-675, Minnesota Power shall submit a plan to the Commission to credit any fu ture 
proceeds to ratepayers. ” 
30. Is it the intent of the signatories that , in all future surplus land and other real property 
transactions where their property is partially in rate base and partially held for the 
shareholders, as was the case in Docket No. E015/PA -20-675 for the Hydro land sale, all 
of the proceeds will be credited to ratepayers as was done for the Hydro land sales in 
Docket No. E015/PA -20-675?  
31.  Is there an estimate of surplus land or other real property that has been designated for 
sale to be included under this provision at this time?  
32. If so, is there an estimate of the property value and what portion is presently in rate base? If there is some other intent of this provision , please provide greater detail.

Additional Info: PUC 33-36 ALLETE, GPP, and CIP QUESTION
content:
Staff  Information Request  (PUC -Nos. 33 -36) 
 
33. The Partners have committed to retain ALLETE /MP’s current workforce for two years 
including maintaining the current senior management of ALLETE /MP as part of the 
settlement stipulation submitted to the Commission by the Department of 
Commerce on July 11, 2025.  
Request:  
a) Why was the retention period for the current workforce agreed to not ten (10) 
years or at the least ﬁve (5) years?  
b) What happens at the expiration of IBEW Local 31  Collective Bargaining 
Agreement  in January 2028?  
c) What is the average number of years of commitment to retain the workforce 
of an acquired utility company in a typical  acquisition transaction by an 
Equity investment ﬁrm?  
34. The Partners stated that they are committed to maintaining ALLETE/MP headquarters in Duluth for the long term . 
Request:  
a) What is the minimum time period in years the Partners intend to retain Duluth, Minnesota as the headquarters of ALLETE /MP?  
i. 5 years  
ii. 10 years  
iii. 15 years  
35. Considering  MP’ s latest rate case settlement and the current  Acquisition process 
which likely will not be ﬁnalized until  late 2025, the likelihood of MP being able to ﬁle 
a rate case with the Commission at the end of 2025 absent the commitment 
appears low.  
Request : 
a) Explain in detail why a stay out from ﬁling a rate case for at minimum  ﬁve (5) 
years would not be reasonable . 
b) Identify any  measurable beneﬁt s that would accrue  to ratepayers from MP 
ﬁling a rate case  in 2026.  
c) Comparing ﬁling a rate case in 2026 and 2030, which of the two would provide more measurable beneﬁts to ratepayers and align better with public 
interest?  
36. The Clean Firm Technology per Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691, subd. 1(b) , means a carbon 
free resource , that can be dispatched and provide energy continuously 50 0r more 
hours. The Partners committed Alloy Parent to invest $50 million in a clean ﬁrm 
technology fund that would be created by MP . Alloy Parent would pay $16.67  million 
installment s to the fund every two years until the fund reaches the $50 million mark.  
The Agreement with the Department stated that contributions would not be 
recoverable . 
Request:  
a) What would this money be spent on in the short -term in the next 5 years?  
b) Are there any speciﬁc projects earmarked for this fund?  
c) Why are the Partners (CPP and GIP/BlackRock) not directly responsible for 
contributing to the fund instead of using the Alloy  Parent? 
d) Please e xplain why it cannot be expected that Alloy Parent  would take on 
more debt to contribute to the fund , thereby resulting in larger rate increase 
requests . 
e) Explain in detail how the costs of projects  ﬁnanced by contributions to clean 
ﬁrm technology fund would be recovered .

Additional Info: AFL-CIO
content:
August  27, 2025 
 
Mr. Mike  Bull                   
Acting  Executive  Secretary  
Minnesota  Public Utilities  Commission  
Suite  350  
121-  7th Place  East  
St. Paul,  MN 55101 - 2147 
 
Dear  Mr. Bull,  
 
I write  on behalf  of Minnesota  AFL -CIO  to urge  the Minnesota  Public Utilities  Commission  to approve the proposed  sale  of 
ALLETE  to infrastructure  investment  funds managed  by Global Infrastructure Partners  and  the Canadian  Pension Plan  
Investment  Board. The Minnesota  AFL -CIO  represents  1,000 local unions, representing, 300,000 union members, including  
multiple  thousands  of men  and  women  that  live and  work  in Northeast  Minnesota. ALLETE  and  Minnesota  Power  have  
played an important role  in the lives  of union households  in Northeast  Minnesota  for generations  — delivering  reliable  
power, creating  family -supporting  jobs,  and  fostering  economic  development.  
 
The unions  most  directly  affected  by the Commission’s  decision  in this  case  — including  International  Brotherhood  of 
Electrical Workers  Local  31 and  unions  affiliated  with  the Minnesota  Building  Trades  — have  taken  a hard  look  and  
concluded  that  the sale  is the best  way  to protect  their  members’  interests  in a healthy, well -functioning  utility.  The  
Minnesota  AFL -CIO  agrees. The modest  and  manageable  risks  associated  with  the proposed  sale  are far outweighed  by 
the risks  Northeast  Minnesotans  face  if ALLETE  is forced  to go it alone. Additional  commitments  negotiated  by Local  31, 
the Minnesota  Department  of Commerce and  Energy  Cents  Coalition  further ensure  that  the sale  is consistent  with  the 
public interest.  
 Like  other investor- owned  utilities,  Minnesota  Power is subject  to democratic  oversight  through the Commission,  which  
limits  the rates  utilities  charge and  the profits  they  earn; requires  them  to operate in a transparent  manner for the benefit  of 
the public;  and  provides  extensive opportunities  for public participation  in planning. None of these rules  and  requirements  
change if ownership  of the utility  changes  from  stockholders  to infrastructure investors, whose funding  comes  largely  from  
public and  labor -management  pension funds.  
 
Comments  submitted  by the Minnesota  Building  and  Construction Trades  Council  detail  the danger to working  people  if 
Minnesota  Power were forced  to rely  on third  parties  for power generation and  other essential  functions  because  the utility  
lacked access  to affordable  capital.  The Minnesota  AFL -CIO  recognizes  the critical  importance of keeping  control  over 
critical  infrastructure in the hands  of regulated  entities,  and  we are concerned  that  excess ive reliance on unregulated  third  
parties  could compromise  the integrity  of the system,  weaken democratic  control  and  oversight, and  undermine the 
economic  and  social  gains  that  Minnesota  Power has  historically  delivered.  
 
The best  way  to prevent  these harms  and  to protect  the progress  we
 have  made  is to ensure that  Minnesota  Power  has  the 
necessary  resources  to build  the clean, reliable  energy  system  we need. This  is especially  true  at a time  when we face  
economic  uncertainty  and  almost  daily  attacks  from  the current  administration  on working  people, and  on Minnesota’s  
plans  for a just  energy  transition. We thank  the Commission  for its attention  and  ask you  to approve the proposed  
transaction. 
  
Sincerely,  
 
 
 
Bernie Burnham      Brad  Lehto  
President      Secretary/Treasurer

Docket Number:  E-015/PA -24-198  Date of Request:  March 26, 2025  
Requested From: Minnesota Power    Response Due:  April 1, 2025   
Analyst Requesting Information:  Robert Manning  
Type of Inquiry:  
 Financial   Rate of Return   Rate Design  
 Engineering   Forecasting   Conservation  
 Cost of Service   CIP X Other: Property Acquisition  
 
If you be lieve your responses are proprietary, please indicate.  
 
Request 
Number 1  Please file into e -Dockets the 2024 10K, filed with SEC on February 13, 2025, 
referenced on page 3 of John D. Quackenbush’s Rebuttal Testimony of March 4, 
2025.  
Request 
Number 2  Which witnesses would be best positioned to speak on the following issues?  
a) Potential limitations on the capital structure of Minnesota Power and/or 
Allete as a condition of the sale.  
b) The willingness of Minnesota Power to accept an extension of the deadline for final adjudication of its next rate case beyond the standard 9 months plus 60 days for the Commission to fully investigate the question of the proper return on equity and capital  structure for Minnesota Power as a 
utility owned by private equity, as opposed to a publicly owned utility.  
c) Reconciliation of the need for capital described in testimony in this case, the capital needs describe in the SEC 10k, and the Integrated Resource Plan filed in Docket 25 -127.   
d) How the merger influenced IRP planning for Docket 25 -127, including 
resource choice.  
Request 
Number 3  For any regulated utility currently with an ownership share of 40%  in the last 25 
years by either partner in the ALLETE acquisition, or majority owned by the 
partners combined, please provide the actual and regulated capital structure at 
the time of acquisition and at the time that the partner’s ownership share 
dropped below 40% and the partners’ combined no longer control majority 
ownership, or the current time, if either partner is still at least a 40% 
shareholder of the utility, and/ or the partners combi ned own a majority share.  
Request 
Number 4  Will ALLETE and Minnesota Power commit to using an “all -in” allocation for the 
determination of retail rates in future rate cases, where all transmission 
facilities revenues are used to offset costs?

Additional Info: PUC 5 - 6 ALLETE, GPP, and CIP QUESTION
content:
PUC Staff Information Request  (PUC 5  and PUC 6 ) 
 
5. What is the current make -up of the ALLETE Board of Directors with regard to 
independent directors? What is the current make -up of the ALLETE Board of 
Directors with regard to gender balance, tribal representation, minority 
representation and veteran status as identiﬁed in Minnesota Statutes section 
216C .51 to encourage diversity of thought and experience?   How would that change 
if the transaction was approved?  
 
6. Please identify and describe the mechanism or mechanisms in the transaction or 
settlement documents that will guarantee that the Partners will provide Alloy Parent  
with the capital needed to fund Minnesota Power at the level necessary for the utility to comply with state law and continue to provide safe, reliable and affordable service to customers of Minnesota Power.   How would the Commission enforce 
those mechanis ms should the Partners fail to do so?

content:
This message may be from an external email source.
Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT Services Security
Operations Center.From: Tyler Mcgovern
To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: Blackrock buying Minnesota Power?
Date: Wednesday, August 27, 2025 7:20:24 AM
You don't often get email from tylermcgovern1789@gmail.com. Learn why this is important
 How is this even legal for a private equity business to by a public service from Minnesotans?
This will result in increased prices, less reliable service, and not to mention is just plainwrong! I would like to know how a public service my tax payers dollars have been supportingall these years can be sold to a private company?? 
Thanks Tyler McGovern
